Prof. Henning,

I represent whistleblowers and I have also participated in internal investigations, so I have seen the problem from both sides (I am also a former AUSA but that was a long time ago). As you know, whistleblowers in health care fraud cases have led to billions of dollars of recoveries for the government. It is unlikely that the government would have been able to recoup anything but a small fraction of these losses without the assistance of the whistleblower. It remains to be seen, however, what impact whistleblowers will have under Dodd-Frank. These cases are going to be much more complicated and the government's resources remain limited.
So I expect that what will happen is that more cases may be initiated by the USAO but much of the leg work will still fall on independent counsel working for the company. Also, it is always going to be easier for the government to proceed civilly, which is why few qui tam complaints have led to criminal prosecutions. So, I suspect that while there may be more investigations and maybe more recoveries, the end result will still be DPAs and NPAs, and internal investigations that exculpate corporate boardrooms.

Sounds like you need a new job.

Speaking as someone who's job once was part of a union and one who's job is now non-union I see both sides of the plate. The evils of unions have been said here clearly enough and often times they do abuse power to the disadvantage even of their own members some times, without them the flood gates open in the opposite direction.

My employer, in spite of record profits and stock highs for years now. They have lowered raises, lowered the starting rate for employees, cut back vacation times, do not replace employees who are lost or fired and just continue to put more work on a shrinking work force, the cost of benefits has gone up, threaten to fire if the word union is mentioned, fire people for flimsy excuses who are still on the older higher pay scale, all while talking about how great they are to their employees. Businesses have learned to balance on matchsticks because the big guys have an out when they see the fall coming, and they don't care about the little guys who get crushed in the process. Without unions to protect the employees they are helpless against it. If you think for one second the educators of your children will stand any better against politicians, take a good look at your local politicians.

I am not saying unions don't need work or are the only solution, but I just know what it like to have to consider giving up the job you have loved for years because the people pulling the strings choose to place them around your neck.

I am not sure that diehard conservatives are capable of joining the 21st century. One can point out all day that they've been wrong on every issue that ever came down the pike -- women's political and reproductive rights, child labor, unions, isolationism, unfettered capitalism, melding of church and state, slavery, race relations, creationism and prayer in schools, same-sex marriage, sacrificing the environment, shrinking of voting rights. They'll believe what they're going to believe, and no amount of evidence will sway them.

One need only look at their preferred methods of expanding their party. Instead of adjusting with the times and trying to accommodate women, or gays, or people of color, they stick to their anti-abortion, anti-immigrant, anti-gay stands, and they get condescending and insulting when few see fit to join them. Things are going to get much worse for the Republican Party before they get better.

Richard, the so-called conservatives (who are actually radical - the Weathermen would be right at home with them) won't participate in the conversation at all. At least the liberals and moderates (remember moderates? we're not quite extinct yet) will talk.

With all due respect Richard, I'm a liberal but I have no discomfort in participating in this conversation. Brooks is demonstrating more objectivity than usual but he oversimplifies and still clings to rather questionable verities. You could for example argue that the sainted Ronald Reagan was in many ways the progenitor of the process (in which Brooks personally played a role) whereby the Republican party has come to be dominated by a series of isms most of which are either incoherent or founded on faulty reasoning. Economic conservatism with supply side theories. Evangelical conservatism with its theocratic views. Tea partyism which is an inchoate stew of nativist anger. Neoconservatism with its extreme nationalism and peculiar attitude to the sanctity of Israel. Libertarianism with its attempt to turn the clock back to the gold standard and a sort of imaginary agrarian/early industrial society.

At the risk of being snarky, conservatism has led to the ossification of their minds.
they no longer seem to be able to look forward. They idolize the past and attribute all the ills of society to liberal activities.

It is the same mentality that rejected "Origin of the Species" and clings to outmoded economic ideology. Great ideas have come form the past, but they were formulated in a time when the world was limited to a few miles from home, except for those who could afford long ocean voyages. Even then there were theories of human societies that we recognize today that were just plain wrong. For instance the English view of which societies were advanced and which were primitive.

Modern communications and travel have changed the nature of the world we live in and the conservatives seem unable to adjust to it. We have more knowledge accessible from our keyboards, than the greatest scholars of the past could contemplate. From ancient philosophy to atomic theory and the nature of the universe.

Going back to earlier times in economics, social relations, and even government is no longer and option. To remain relevant, conservatives need to join the 21st century.

No, it has nothing to do with family pressures. If you read the study, they were evaluating IDENTICAL resumes where the only difference was the name. THe professors were evaluating the same resume, and concluding the one with the male name was better qualified and deserved a higher salary. Yes, family pressure is an issue, but it's not the point of this study.

The issue isn't whether "Woman == Man" or whether there is value in diversity. The issue is whether prejudice keeps women from getting equal opportunity in science. Remember, equal opportunity doesn't guarantee equal results. But don't you think a woman who is promising should get her chance? Even if there are fewer promising women than men? In fact it looks as if prejudice is what makes it seem as if there are fewer promising women in science. What a dreadful waste!

Sorry if I was unclear--I just used the race case as an example. My point is that different names can be associated with a wide variety of stereotypes (and expectations) that have nothing to do with gender. If that's the case for the names John and Jennifer, the study's results would be skewed.
And (adding to Alyssa's fine point) because it is impossible to sort out the class vs. race biases in the example you provide.  John and Jennifer are not exclusively white names.
Actually, you may have a point. Joe-Bob and Eunice vs John and Cookie.....that might be an interesting study.....

I wonder--why stick with only two names (John and Jennifer) rather than using a rotation of various male and female names? Couldn't the selection of these two specific names have introduced bias independent of gender? I wouldn't be surprised if John did even better against, say, Jamal, than against Jennifer.
